newsitem.title: USA: Andrew sees order growth accelerating.
newsitem.headline: Andrew sees order growth accelerating.

text.p: Andrew Corp said Thursday it expects its order growth to accelerate in the second half of its current fiscal year, and the company is "on track" to meet analysts' earnings estimates for the year.
"We do anticipate that the order growth will accelarate in the second half," president, chairman and chief executive Floyd English said in a teleconference.
Andrew reported an 18 percent increase in orders in its second quarter ended March 31. English said the picked-up growth will also impact sales number.

"I think we have a good chance of meeting the previous six months (order growth) numbers and maybe excceding them," English said, adding in the first fiscal half the company posted a 22 percent rise in orders.
According to First Call, the consensus of analysts' earnings estimates for the company's current fiscal year is $1.27 a share, up from $0.98 a share in the prior fiscal year.
Earlier, the company reported second quarter earnings of $0.28 a share versus $0.20 last year.
"We viewed the numbers in a positive sense and believe that we are on track for the year," English said.
"When we say we're on track, we're generally on track to meet analysts' expectations," English said.

Shares of Andrew tumbled more than 34 percent on the second quarter results, and analysts pointed to a shortfall in revenues. The company reported revenues for the quarter of $208.22 million versus $183.16 million, but analysts had expected about $230 million to $235 million, or flat with fiscal first quarter's sales of $231.66 million.
English said the company was surprised by what he called the market's "severe reaction" to the results. He said the shortfall in sales was largely "a question of timing".
English said revenues from Andrew's accessories business, including cases, batteries and other items related to wireless phones, were $15 million below the first quarter.

The strong U.S. dollar had about a $4 million negative impact versus first quarter, and a delay in some orders for PCS (personal communications services) and other wireless infrastructure cut sales sequentially by about $5 million to $10 million, the company said.
"If you add those numbers, I think you have more than enough" to explain the lower-than-expected sales figure, English said.
Accessories are typically strongest in the company's fiscal first quarter because of holiday sales, and weakest in the second quarter, English said.
"It was a significant decline and frankly a little more than we anticipated, but the December quarter strength in accessories was a little more than we anticipated," he said.
English said the hike in interest rates delayed infrastructure sales. In March, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25 percent.
Severe weather in many areas likely delayed construction and led to inventory buildup, also slowing new sales.

"The infrastructure market has traditionally been nervous when interest rates are increased, and that causes the operators to hesitate, to review their models and capital expenditures," English said. "Whether they change or not, they generally review."
But English said Andrew does not believe it has lost market share in any of its products, and has likely gained share in towers and shelters.
"The question we're addressing here is really a question of timing," English said. "We believe we are on track to have 1997 a good year for Andrew."
((--Chicago newsdesk, 312-408-8787))
